article:
'Inhibition of return' (IOR) refers to an orientation mechanism that briefly
enhances (for approximately 100-300 milliseconds (ms)) the speed and accuracy
with which an object is detected after the object is attended, but then impairs
detection speed and accuracy (for approximately 500-3000 milliseconds). IOR is
usually measured with a cue-response paradigm, in which a person presses a
button when he or she detects a target stimulus following the presentation of a
cue that indicates the location in which the target will appear. Oftentimes, the
cue is exogenous (or peripheral), Posner MI & Cohen Y (1984) Components of
visual orienting. Chapter in Attention & Performance X, (Bouma H. and Bouwhuis
D., eds) pp 531-56, Erlbaum as opposed to endogenous because endogenous
cues do not tend to activate IOR. Although IOR occurs for both visual
and auditory stimuli, IOR is greater for visual stimuli, and is
studied more often than auditory stimuli.
